title-group.article-title: Does Excluding Some Groups From Research Designs Improve Statistical Power?

author-notes.corresp: Torsten Biemann, University of Cologne, Venloer Street 151-153, Cologne 50923, Germany Email: biemann@wiso.uni-koeln.de

abstract.p: This article aims to contribute to a controversy over whether excluding some small or incomplete groups from a sample improves statistical power in group research designs (designs that relate group-level characteristics to group-level outcome measures). In a series of simulation studies, we examined the trade-off between lower reliability and smaller sample size that occurs when very small groups, or incomplete groups are excluded. Distinguishing reflective aggregation models (where scores for different group members are interchangeable) and formative aggregation models (where scores for different group members are not interchangeable), we analyzed the impact that the number of groups, the number of individuals within groups, intraclass correlation (ICC[1]) values, and interrater agreement have on statistical power. The results provided evidence that excluding groups is mostly ill-advised and may fail to improve the conclusions that researchers draw from their results. Common practice and the assumptions that researchers make when excluding groups from their samples are discussed.

body.p: In field settings, researchers often have to rely on samples that are incomplete and that contain units of different sizes (e.g., work groups with a varying number of members). In group research, there has been some debate about whether it is justified to exclude some small or incomplete groups before data analyses are performed (Dawson, 2003). Furthermore, different researchers provide different rationales to justify the smallest acceptable group size and the exclusion of smaller groups (see Moreland, 2010). Some authors have excluded groups from their analysis that contained less than an ad hoc defined minimum number of team members. For instance, authors have excluded groups with less than three (e.g., Klein, Conn, Smith, & Sorra, 2001; Lichtenstein, Alexander, Jinnett, & Ullman, 1997; Simons, Pelled, & Smith, 1999; West & Schwenk, 1996), six (e.g., Schneider, Ehrhart, Mayer, Saltz, & Niles-Jolly, 2005), or 11 members (e.g., Pfeffer & Langton, 1988). Other researchers have excluded groups based on the percentage of group members sampled. The minimum percentage of group members that researchers have considered sufficient ranges from 40% to 100% (Ancona & Caldwell, 1992; Eigel & Kuhnert, 1996; Jehn, Northcraft, & Neale, 1999; Mayo, Pastor, & Meindl, 1996; O’Reilly, Caldwell, & Barnett, 1989; Schippers, Den Hartog, Koopman, & Wienk, 2003). Despite this lack of agreement about the exclusion of groups and its relevance for research results, few people have addressed this issue systematically. Nevertheless, some exceptions can be found.

For example, several articles have examined the attenuation of effect sizes (ES) due to incomplete samples. Timmerman (2005), for instance, examined the amount of variance in group performance that is explained by a group-level predictor under different types of individual-level nonresponse (e.g., random deletion of group members; systematic selection of members). Timmerman found that randomly deleting group members from the analyses attenuated group-level relationships between group characteristics and group performance. Similarly, Allen, Stanley, Williams, and Ross (2007), as well as Newman and Sin (2009), have evaluated the extent to which nonresponse in groups decreased the average observed correlation between work group diversity and outcome measures. Allen and colleagues (2007), for example, examined groups containing 10 members, with a true correlation of r = .60 between a group-level predictor (team diversity) and a group-level outcome. They found that a 40% random nonresponse was associated with average observed correlation coefficients that ranged between r = .40 and r = .50. Previous research has thus shown that including small or incomplete groups is associated with underestimating true ES, due to the lower reliability that aggregate measures have in small or incomplete groups (Allen et al., 2007; Nesterkin & Ganster, in press; Newman & Sin, 2009; Timmerman, 2005). Accordingly, excluding small or incomplete groups before data analysis can be a means to counteract attenuation effects due to unreliability. However, excluding groups can have desirable and undesirable effects.

Discussing desirable and undesirable effects of excluding small or incomplete groups raises the more fundamental question of whether and how excluding groups affect statistical power in group research designs. Statistical power is defined as the probability of detecting an effect in a sample when a true effect exists in the population. Statistical power provides important information about the quality of statistical inference, especially a researcher’s propensity to draw false conclusions from results. Accordingly, statistical power is an important criterion for deciding whether to exclude small or incomplete groups from group research designs. Statistical power depends on several factors, including the true underlying ES, reliability, alpha level, and sample size (Cohen, 1988). When researchers exclude some groups, a trade-off thus occurs between two competing determinants of statistical power. On the one hand, excluding small or incomplete groups may improve the reliability of group measures. On the other hand, excluding such groups will reduce the number of higher level units and thus the sample size. As a result, excluding unreliable (i.e., small or incomplete) groups from a sample will not necessarily improve statistical inferences by raising statistical power. The reason is that sample size is more strongly associated with statistical power than is the unreliability of measures at the group level.

To study group- or organizational-level phenomena, higher level concepts are often calculated from lower level data (Harrison & Klein, 2007). For instance, research has conceived measures of organizational climate as aggregates of individual-level perceptions of psychological climate (Glick, 1985; James et al., 2008). Power analyses have seldom been presented for such designs, despite the fact that much research focuses on higher level measures, such as group outcomes (for comparable analyses in multilevel designs with outcome measures at the individual level, see, for example, Raudenbush & Liu, 2000; Scherbaum & Ferreter, 2009; Snijders & Bosker, 1993; see also Murray, 1998, for group-randomized trials). To address this problem, we present power analyses for designs that are frequently used in group research—designs that examine how group-level predictors (e.g., age diversity) are related to group-level outcomes (e.g., group performance). Our main goal, however, is to examine whether excluding small or incomplete groups from those research designs affects statistical power positively. To answer this question, we consider a number of relevant factors. These include the number of groups studied, the number of individuals in those groups, the within- and between-level variance of the individual measures, and the reliability of the group-level measures. Furthermore, we distinguish between formative and reflective aggregation models as they have different implications for the calculation of statistical power in group research designs (for a more general discussion of formative and reflective measurement, see Bollen & Lennox, 1991; Diamantopoulos & Winklhofer, 2001; Howell, Breivik, & Wilcox, 2007; MacKenzie, Podsakoff, & Jarvis, 2005). Based on these considerations, we conduct Monte Carlo simulations to estimate power in group research designs and to address the question of whether excluding small or incomplete groups improves statistical power.

sec.title: Formative and Reflective Aggregation Models
sec.p: In formative aggregation models, individual measures are not interchangeable indicators of a common construct. The group-level construct is a compilation of individual-level attributes and is expected to measure phenomena that are not evident at the individual level (Bliese, 2000). For example, group mean age or age diversity is calculated as an aggregate of individual age across all group members (i.e., group mean age, standard deviation of age within groups). In studies of age diversity, for example, age-heterogeneous groups can be sampled and included in data analyses. When group means are used as aggregates, researchers may want to calculate indexes of within-group agreement (such as rWG) to assess the degree of similarity of group members. However, as individual measures are not interchangeable indicators of a common construct in formative models, the completeness of groups rather than their within-group agreement determines whether the group-level aggregate is assessed well. In an incomplete group, aggregates of age (e.g. the age diversity among 50% of group members) may not fully capture the intended higher level concept. By contrast, if all group members are sampled, the group-level variable is assumed to be without measurement error (Lüdtke et al., 2008). That is, all group members must be included in a formative measurement model to capture the group construct. Examples include most group aggregates of individuals’ demographic and personality characteristics, such as age, educational background, extraversion, and need for structure. Accordingly, in formative aggregation models, the decision to exclude groups (higher level units) is based on some minimum percentage of missing observations deemed acceptable per group (percent complete). Ideally, information from all units is available, but this is often not the case, so researchers must decide on an acceptable percentage of missing responses.

A key characteristic of reflective aggregation models is the assumption that lower level units (e.g., individuals) are interchangeable. The group-level construct is a composite of individual attributes (Bliese, 2000; MacKenzie et al., 2005). For example, research has assessed charismatic leadership based on aggregates of subordinates’ ratings of leadership styles (House, 1977). Subordinates are all exposed to their supervisors’ leadership behavior, and group members are likely to share perceptions of that behavior. To assess the extent of leaders’ charismatic leadership, subordinates are considered equivalent instruments of measurement. Their ratings are assumed to agree, apart from unreliability (see classical measurement theory; e.g., Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994). Accordingly, in assessing charismatic leadership it is irrelevant which group members contribute to the aggregated value, because all group members are thought of as equivalent measurement instruments that contribute repeated measures of a common group construct. The number of group members (i.e., indicators) only has an impact on the reliability of the group-level measure. Reflective aggregates of lower level units become more reliable with increasing unit size. As a consequence, a random choice of individuals from each group is an appropriate sampling strategy. It is irrelevant whether a small number of observations within a group results from a population of smaller groups or the fact that not all group members could be sampled (Kenny, Manetti, Pierro, Livi, & Kashy, 2002). Accordingly, for reflective measures, it is appropriate to consider the minimum number of individuals sampled within a group or within-group agreement as a criterion for the exclusion of groups. ICC(1) values serve as indicators of interrater reliability in reflective measurement models (Bliese, 2000; James, 1982). ICC(1) is defined as the amount of between-group variance divided by the sum of between-group and within-group variance. In actual research settings, ICC(1) values mostly range between 0.05 and 0.30 (Bliese, 2000). High ICC(1) values indicate low within-group variance, which is equivalent to high consensus in the assessment of lower level units with regard to the higher level construct.

sec.title: Group Size and Statistical Power in Group Research Designs
sec.p: To provide estimates of statistical power in group research designs, we examined the relationship between an aggregated group-level predictor and a group-level outcome measure in simulation studies that considered the distinction between formative and reflective aggregation models. Our simulations systematically addressed three factors that influence statistical power. First, the true underlying ES was set to represent small, medium, or large effects (r = .10, r = .30 or r = .50; Cohen, 1988). Second, the average number of lower level units sampled within higher level units was varied between 1 and 20 for reflective measures and between 10% and 100% for formative measures. Third, for reflective aggregation models, the ICC(1) was set to one of four values (ICC[1] = 0.05, 0.10, 0.20, 0.30). In all of the simulations, the alpha level was set to 5% (one-tailed testing). Simulations were conducted using the R language for statistical computing (R Development Core Team, 2010; the code is available on request).

Our research question was whether and how excluding some groups affect statistical power in group research designs. To address this question, we examined how excluding incomplete groups (formative aggregation model) and smaller groups (reflective aggregation model) affected statistical power.

sec.title: Setting 1: Excluding groups with low response rates (formative aggregation model)
sec.p: Our first set of simulations examined the effects of excluding groups with low response rates. We did this by systematically varying ES and sample composition. We based our simulations on a sample of 200 groups that generated formative measures of a group-level construct (e.g., mean age or gender diversity). We designed the sample so that response rates varied across groups. In 20 groups, data from all individuals were available (100% response within these groups). In 20 other groups, the response rate was 90%. In another 20 groups, the response rate was 80%, and so on. This way, the sample that we analyzed contained groups with response rates that varied between 10% and 100%. Using that sample, we tested whether excluding groups with low response rates indeed improved statistical power.

sec.title: Setting 2: Excluding smaller groups (reflective aggregation model)
sec.p: The next set of simulations examined how statistical power changed when smaller groups were excluded from a reflective aggregation model. We varied ES, sample composition, and within-group agreement (ICC-1). Again, simulations were based on a sample of 200 groups with group sizes, containing 3 to 10 members per group. It is important to note that the actual sizes of the groups that a researcher studies could take on any value. What we are referring to here, and throughout this article, is not really the size of a group, but rather the number of group members who generate data for the analyses. We examined how excluding groups based on their size affected statistical power. We first computed power estimates for the full sample of 200 groups and then recalculated power after groups with three members, four members, and so on had been removed from the sample.

sec.title: Setting 3: Excluding unreliable groups (reflective aggregation model)
sec.p: Finally, we conducted power analyses to test how excluding the most unreliable groups (i.e., groups with low intraclass correlation (1) [ICC(1)] values) affected statistical power. Again, we varied ES, sample composition, and ICC(1). We first computed statistical power for the full sample, and then omitted the most unreliable groups (groups with little member agreement) in a stepwise fashion and recalculated statistical power.

In all three settings, power estimates were based on 10,000 replications. Aggregate measures were calculated from the average of individual-level measures (M = 0; SD = 1). To estimate statistical power, the percentage of studies that produced a statistically significant result was calculated. Because the true relationship between the predictor and the outcome measure was known to be positive, each significant, positive ES estimate would have led to a correct inference in hypothesis testing, whereas a significant negative or nonsignificant estimate would have led to an incorrect decision (a beta-error). In summary, we calculated statistical power based on the percentage of correct conclusions from 10,000 replications.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the following material, we focus on results regarding our research question (i.e., whether excluding small, incomplete, or unreliable teams is associated with higher power in group research designs). General information on statistical power in formative and reflective group research designs appears in Appendix A and Appendix B. Appendix A shows how statistical power depends on ES, the number of groups sampled, the number of individuals within groups, and unreliability (ICC[1] values) in reflective aggregation models. Appendix B shows how statistical power depends on ES, the number of groups sampled, and the percentage of individuals sampled within groups in formative aggregation models.

sec.title: Setting 1: Excluding Groups With Low Response Rates (Formative Aggregation Model)
sec.p: Table 1 reports results from power analyses in Setting 1, where we examined how excluding groups based on a minimum response rate affected power (formative aggregation model). In all analyses, we used group-level mean values as aggregates. First, consider our simulation results for a medium ES (i.e., a correlation of r = .30 between group-level predictor and group-level outcome). In the first run of our simulations, we examined all groups in the sample, including those with very low response rates (i.e., groups for which only 10 % of all group members were sampled). For this analysis, the total sample size was 200. Table 1 shows that this setting yielded an estimate of 0.80 for statistical power. If a researcher only included groups with a response rate of at least 30%, 40 groups would be eliminated from the sample, which would reduce the final sample size to 160. In this analysis, power increased to 0.89. When only complete groups were analyzed (i.e., groups were excluded when the response rate was less than 100%), sample size dropped to 20, and statistical power was only 0.37. Apparently, two conflicting effects exist that must be taken into account when groups are excluded from a sample. On the one hand, including groups with very low response rates (e.g., 10%) reduces the expected correlation between group characteristic and outcome, which has a negative impact on statistical power. On the other hand, being strict by eliminating many groups (e.g., only analyzing complete groups), reduces the sample size and also reduces statistical power. There is thus a curvilinear relationship between the exclusion of incomplete groups and statistical power; neither keeping all the groups in the sample nor excluding any incomplete groups will maximize statistical power.

caption.p: Estimations of Statistical Power With Varying Cutoff Criteria in Formative Aggregation Models

tr.th: Groups are excluded if response rate is lower than

fn.p: Note: Criterion for the exclusion of groups: sampling ratio per group in percentage (percent complete). ES = effect size. Power estimates are based on 10,000 replications. The total sample size is kept constant at 200 individuals.

fn.label: a
fn.p: In this column, no groups are excluded, as the minimum response rate was set to 10% in the simulation (i.e., no group has a response rate below 10%).

sec.p: Overall, in this formative measurement setting with a medium ES, statistical power would be optimized if a researcher chose a minimum response rate within groups of 30% or 40%. Smaller and larger cutoff points yielded slightly smaller power estimates. This was echoed in simulation results with small and large ES. For small ES, statistical power peaked when setting the cutoff point for group response rates between 30% and 50%. For large ES, statistical power reached its maximum (i.e., 1.00) for response rates of 20% to 70%. Thus, excluding groups with response rates lower than 20% maximized statistical power, whereas power decreased again only when a very large number of groups was excluded (i.e., all groups with a response rate below 70%).

sec.title: Setting 2: Excluding Smaller Groups (Reflective Aggregation Model)
sec.p: In Settings 2 and 3, we conducted simulations to examine how excluding groups affected statistical power in reflective aggregation models. For that purpose, simulation settings were changed in two ways. First, we varied group size rather than the percentage of respondents sampled. We ran simulations with a maximum of 5, 10, or 20 individuals per group (kmax). Second, we varied ICC(1) values to capture how interrater reliability affects power estimates. Table 2 shows the results from the simulations. In this instance, we examined the effects of excluding smaller groups based on a varying minimum number (kmin) of individuals per group. kmin describes the minimum number of individuals (lower level units). kmax indicates the maximum group size. This maximum number of individuals per group was set to 5, 10, and 20, and each group size from kmin to kmax was represented by 10 groups. For example, assume that a researcher analyzed groups in a setting where the maximum group size was 20 (i.e., kmin = 20), an ICC of 0.10, and there was a medium ES. The resulting sample size was 200 groups, and the statistical power was 0.28 (see Table 2). If a researcher excluded all groups with fewer than three members (kmin = 3), the sample size would be reduced to 180 groups. Even though the overall sample was smaller, statistical power could increase to 0.34. Excluding groups with fewer than three members increased the probability of correctly detecting a significant relationship between an aggregated group characteristic and group outcome, albeit slightly (see Table 2 for detailed results).

caption.p: Estimates of Statistical Power With Varying ICC(1) Values and Minimum Group Size as Cutoff Criteria in Reflective Aggregation Models

fn.p: Note: kmin = minimum number of individuals per team; kmax = maximum team size; ES = effect size; ICC = Intraclass correlation. Power estimates are based on simulation results with 10,000 replications. The total sample size is kept constant at 200 individuals, but is reduced when smaller groups are excluded.

sec.p: Generally, omitting smaller groups from the overall sample had rather small positive effects on statistical power. Only when groups with just one member were retained did power estimates decline notably. Excluding groups with five or more members affected power estimates more negatively. This was supported by additional analyses in which we excluded groups with 6, 7, and more members (detailed results of these analyses are available from the authors on request).

sec.title: Setting 3: Excluding Unreliable Groups (Reflective Aggregation Model)
sec.p: Setting 3 allowed us to examine how excluding groups with low within-group agreement would affect statistical power in group research designs. Within-group agreement is typically measured by rWG indices (James, Demaree, & Wolf, 1984). For a single item, this index defined is as follows:

is constant within a sample, so rWG relies only on the within-group variance of a variable. Based on these considerations, we excluded groups that yielded the highest within-group variance (
s

2
). The factors that affect statistical power were the same as in Setting 2. Then, we excluded groups based on within-group agreement (i.e., high within-group variance). We first excluded the 5% of groups that yielded the highest within-group variance (groups that were outliers as compared on the 95% confidence interval). This exclusion criterion was then increased in steps of 5%, until 20% of the groups were excluded. For example, for an ES of r = .30, ICC(1) = 0.10, and a group size of 20 members (kmax = 20), statistical power was 0.32 when the 5% of groups with the highest within-group variance were excluded (krel = 95%), 0.34 when 10% of such groups were excluded, and 0.31 when 20% of such groups were excluded. Table 3 shows the simulation results. Those results showed that excluding groups based on within-group agreement produced little variation in statistical power. These findings were similar across Settings 2 and 3. There were only marginal differences between the results based on the two different exclusion criteria (minimum group size and minimum rWG; see Table 3 for detailed results).

caption.p: Estimates of Statistical Power With Varying ICC(1) Values and Minimum Within-Group Agreement as Cutoff Criteria in Reflective Aggregation Models

fn.p: Note: krel = percentage of groups in sample based on within-group agreement; kmax = maximum team size; ES = effect size; ICC = Intraclass correlation. Power estimates are based on simulation results with 10,000 replications. The total sample size is kept constant at 200 individuals, but is reduced when groups with low within-group agreement are excluded.

fn.label: a
fn.p: In this column, no groups are excluded.

sec.p: In summary, power in reflective aggregation models was highest when groups containing only a single group member (or 5 to 10% of the groups with the lowest within-group agreement) were excluded. When groups with two to four members (or 10 to 15% of the groups with the lowest agreement) were also excluded, power increased only slightly, and excluding even more groups had negative effects on power. This basic finding applied to designs with varying ICC(1) and ES values (see Tables 2 and 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this article, we conducted power analyses for multilevel studies that related group characteristics (measured as an aggregate of member characteristics) to outcomes at the group level. Our results confirmed that excluding higher level units often failed to improve statistical power. Thus, statistical power may be at critically low levels in many designs that are frequently encountered in field research. Based on our results, we conclude that excluding smaller groups is an ineffective means of increasing statistical power. In the following material, we recapitulate our results on the determinants of (low) statistical power, and then discuss how our findings may help to guide future research.

sec.title: Determinants of Statistical Power
sec.p: Our simulations showed that three factors shape statistical power, namely, the number of lower level and higher level units, and the population ES. In reflective aggregation models, within-group reliability is a fourth factor that can affect statistical power. With regard to ES, our results suggest that when the ES is small, even large samples can suffer from unsatisfactory low levels of statistical power. This can be seen in Tables 2 and 3, because the maximum power in any of those settings with a small ES was 0.28 (see Table 2 for ICC[1] = 0.30, kmax = 20, and kmin = 2). That is, power always remained below the frequently suggested minimum of 0.80 (Cohen, 1992; Maxwell, 2004). The sample size in these settings varied between 150 and 200 groups. Smaller sample sizes, which are often encountered in group research, would yield even lower power estimates. For medium (r = .30) and large (r = .50) ES in reflective aggregation models, sufficient power can be achieved when ICC(1) values are relatively high. For example, statistical power was 0.75 (0.99) for a medium (large) ES, in a setting with an ICC(1) of 0.20, a minimum group size of two individuals per group, and a maximum group size of 20 (see Table 2). Our results showed that in reflective aggregation models, the number of groups was more important than the number of members. In particular, if ICC(1) values are large, a strategy to maximize power can be to sample many groups, even if this means that fewer individuals are sampled within each group. If within-group reliability is high (i.e., ICC[1] and ICC[2] are high), adding an additional individual to a group that is already part of the sample provides comparatively little new information, whereas adding an individual who is a member of an additional group provides additional, independent information.

sec.title: Low Power in Group Research
sec.p: In view of all the interest that group research has received (e.g., Mathieu, Maynard, Rapp, & Gilson, 2008; Van Knippenberg, De Dreu, & Homan, 2004), it is interesting to note that the samples studied by many researchers still offer low statistical power (because of their small sizes). For example, based on 491 studies, meta-analytical evidence on the relationships between group performance and various group characteristics (e.g., group cohesion and leadership) shows an average sample size of 65 groups and an empirical average ES of r = .23 (our own calculations, based on Balkundi & Harrison, 2006, Beal, Cohen, Burke, & McLendon, 2003; Bell, 2007; Burke et al., 2006; De Dreu & Weingart, 2003; Devine & Philips, 2001; Gully, Incalcaterra, Joshi, & Beaubien, 2002; LePine, Piccolo, Jackson, Mathieu, & Saul, 2008; Stewart, 2006). Another recent meta-analysis on the effects of diversity in teams reported an average sample size of about 78 groups per study (our own calculations, based on Horwitz & Horwitz, 2007). Results suggest that the effects of task-related diversity (e.g., functional expertise, education, and organizational tenure), as well as demographic diversity (e.g., age, gender, and race/ethnicity) on the quality and quantity of group performance is small (Horwitz & Horwitz, 2007). For instance, Horwitz and Horwitz reported that the average unattenuated ES ρ varied between ρ = −0.02 for demographic diversity and the quantity of group performance, and ρ = 0.13 for task-related diversity and the quality of group performance. Assuming a small ES and a sample size of 50 to 100 groups in a formative measurement model (as with diversity measures), our simulations suggest that statistical power would be rather low. For example, in a sample of 100 groups, with a response rate of 100%, our findings suggest that statistical power would be only .26 (see Appendix B). This means that there would be a 74% chance of missing a true effect. Not surprisingly, many diversity studies do not find a significant effect between group diversity and outcome measures (see meta-analyses by Bowers, Pharmer, & Salas, 2000; Horwitz & Horwitz, 2007; Webber & Donahue, 2001). The prevailing interpretation of nonsignificant effects in the literature is that relationships are more complex and that moderator variables may help to explain inconsistent results (Van Knippenberg et al., 2004; see Schmidt, 1996, for a critical view on this issue). In some cases, however, attempts to identify moderator variables may be premature. Instead, low levels of statistical power may have produced insignificant and inconsistent results. The results presented in this article provide evidence that statistical power is still low in many group research designs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: On the one hand, excluding groups with few members leads to higher ES estimates. On the other hand, excluding groups reduces the total sample size and may thus decrease power. Our simulations showed that statistical power hardly changed when different percentages of groups were excluded (for both reflective and formative aggregation models). For reflective aggregation models, we simulated the effects of excluding groups for samples in which the number of individuals per group varied between 1 and 20. We found the highest levels of statistical power when only higher level units with one (or at best two) lower level units were excluded. In formative aggregation models, excluding higher level units with a response rate of less than 30% or 40% optimized power. Excluding more groups did not increase statistical power substantially. We certainly agree that researchers should avoid missing data during data collection. However, with regard to statistical power, excluding medium-sized higher level units (five or more lower level units for reflective constructs and a response rate of 60% or more for formative constructs) from analyses is not justified, based on statistical power. We argue that research designs should optimize the inference that can be reached reliably. Accordingly, we included a number of factors that affect statistical power in our analyses. From our results, we conclude that the positive effects that excluding unreliable groups has on statistical power (due to higher average group-level reliability) are absorbed by a decreasing sample size. This becomes evident for reflective aggregation models in Tables 2 and 3, which showed that statistical power peaked when only a few groups were excluded. For example, with an ICC(1) value of 0.20 and a medium ES, statistical power reached its maximum when only groups with one or two individuals were excluded (Table 2).

Whereas statistical power hardly justifies the exclusion of groups that have at least two members, substantive considerations may still apply, which could lead to the exclusion of some groups. For example, it might be reasonable to exclude groups whose members have worked together for only a short time (e.g., Drach-Zahavy & Somech, 2001; Timmerman, 2005). Including these groups may affect the relationship between group-level constructs (e.g., leadership climate, age diversity) and group-level outcomes, such as group performance. We conclude that a two-step process is appropriate for decisions about excluding groups from a sample. First, for reflective aggregation models, researchers should exclude only those groups in which a single member was observed. In formative aggregation models, we suggest that groups that are less than 20% complete should be excluded. In a second step, theoretical arguments may lead researchers to exclude groups with specific characteristics (e.g., low group tenure), characteristics that might alter the meaning of group-level aggregates in qualitative ways. However, in this case, rather than excluding groups, it might again be more appropriate to include all groups and control the effects of theoretically relevant factors. Furthermore, we join other authors (e.g., Newman & Sin, 2009) in recommending that researchers report both the overall response rate and the response rates within groups, when describing their work. If information about sampling rates were available more often, then meta-analytical researchers could correct ES estimates for attenuation more effectively.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: In our simulations, we examined samples that were composed of groups with evenly spaced and equally distributed group sizes or response rates. For example, we examined samples with 20 groups and a response rate of 100%, 20 groups with a response rate of 90%, and so forth. Conclusions may be different depending on the distribution of group sizes and response rates. To allow researchers to conduct power calculations for specific samples, we provide a script written in the R language for statistical computing (R Development Core Team, 2010). This script calculates statistical power for any sample containing groups with different sizes or response rates, in reflective and formative aggregation models. The script can be downloaded from the first author’s website. It calculates power for user-defined group sizes (percent complete groups), indicating how power changes when groups with a minimum size (minimum completeness) are dropped from the sample.

Our results are also limited in that we exclusively examined univariate settings and did not include a large number of predictors. Further research is needed to estimate statistical power when the decision to exclude groups is based on several variables.

Finally, it is interesting to note that recent methodological work has developed models that circumvent calculating group-level aggregates (such as calculating a mean across group members), but rather treat individual-level values as indicators of latent variables residing at the group level. These models may help to overcome many of the methodological and theoretical problems that are associated with using group-level aggregates as predictors in multilevel models. For example, to predict group-level outcomes from variables at the individual level, Croon and van Veldhoven (2007) suggested a latent variable multilevel model, Lüdtke et al. (2008) describe a multilevel latent covariate model, and Preacher, Zyphur, and Zhang (2010) developed a structural equation approach to mediation in multilevel models. Further research may reveal whether using latent variable models leads to different conclusions regarding the exclusion of small or incomplete groups.

caption.p: Statistical Power in Reflective Aggregation Models, Depending on the Number of Groups, the Number of Individuals Within Groups, ICC(1) Values, and ES

fn.p: Note: k = number of individuals sampled per team; N = number of teams in the sample; ES = effect size. Power estimates are based on simulations with 10,000 replications.

caption.p: Statistical Power in Formative Aggregation Models, Depending on the Number of Groups, the Completeness of Groups (%), and ES

fn.p: Note: k% = percentage of individuals sampled per team; N = number of teams in the sample; ES = effect size. Power estimates are based on simulations with 10,000 replications.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Torsten Biemann is an assistant professor of human resource management at the University of Cologne, Germany. His research interests include careers, group research, multilevel methods, and international human resource management.

Heike Heidemeier received an PhD degree from University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Germany. She is a researcher at RWTH Aachen University. Her research interests include self-evaluation processes, life satisfaction, and workplace achievement goals.
